awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Establishing the Foundations of Black Hole Mass Measurements of AGN Across Cosmic Time
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1

Supermassive black holes are the largest black holes in the universe, ranging from millions to billions of times the mass of the Sun. A major theme in astronomy is understanding how these black holes grew to their enormous masses. This project will investigate the growth of black holes by carrying out observational studies of quasars, which are supermassive black holes that are growing rapidly. Using a method called "echo mapping", the investigators will determine how gas flows around the black holes in quasars and measure the masses of the black holes. This work will use new data analysis tools and software developed by their team that will make it possible to measure the black hole masses with higher accuracy than earlier methods. They will also analyze data from earlier observing projects in order to assemble a large collection of quasars with accurate black hole mass measurements. They  will use these results to develop improved methods to estimate the masses of black holes in the most distant quasars in the universe. This work will provide an important new foundation for studies of black hole growth across the history of the cosmos.   The investigators will work with undergraduate astronomy majors, focusing on conducting research.  They will mentor and advise students considering going on to graduate school, and will provide summer research opportunities to students in the "Cal-Bridge" program.

Part 2

Understanding the growth and evolution of supermassive black holes across cosmic time is a central theme in astronomy. Very distant black holes can only be identified and studied when they are actively growing by accreting matter from their surroundings and shining brightly as quasars. Measuring the masses of the black holes in quasars is a key to understanding how black holes grow and influence their environments. The technique of "echo mapping" is one of the best tools to study the physical properties and black hole masses of quasars. This method uses the variations over time in a quasar's light to map out the distribution and motion of gas around the black hole. The goal of this project is to advance the science of quasar echo mapping through a combination of new observations and the development of new data analysis methods. The investigators will acquire new echo mapping data using several telescopes, and use the data to map the distribution of gas around the black holes. They will apply new data analysis methods developed by our team to interpret echo mapping data in a physical framework that will enable direct determination of the masses of black holes. Finally, they will carry out a uniform re-analysis of all available echo mapping data from earlier work, and use the results to derive an improved calibration of the black hole masses in distant quasars. This work will provide a rigorous new foundation for investigations of black hole growth across the history of the universe.  The investigators will work with undergraduate astronomy majors, focusing on conducting research.  They will mentor and advise students considering going on to graduate school, and will provide summer research opportunities to students in the "Cal-Bridge" program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supermassive black holes in galaxy centers grow during episodes of gas accretion, when they shine brightly as powerful active galactic nuclei (AGN). To understand the history of black hole growth over cosmic time, it is necessary to carry out measurements of the masses and gas accretion rates of supermassive black holes ranging from those in the nearest galaxies out to the most distant observable AGN in the universe.

The central regions of AGN, including the accretion disk and surrounding emission-line regions, have sizes of light-days to light-months, which are too small to be resolved in direct images since these objects are located at distances of millions of light-years. However, it is possible to examine these small structures using the method of reverberation mapping. Reverberation mapping uses the time delays between variations seen in different spectral components of AGN, measured through long-duration monitoring programs, to map out the inner gaseous structures surrounding the black hole. This project encompassed a variety of observational programs aimed at using reverberation mapping and related methods to study black holes ranging from those in nearby galaxies to the most distant known quasars in the universe, and spanning a range of more than four orders of magnitude in black hole mass. Observational programs included both emission-line reverberation mapping, which is used to measure the masses of black holes in AGN, and continuum reverberation mapping, which can be used to determine the sizes of AGN accretion disks. Additionally, new software was developed for measurement of reverberation time delays and evaluating their statistical significance.

Key outcomes from these projects included: (a) Measurement of reverberation time delays and black hole masses in a sample of moderate to high-luminosity AGN using data obtained in long-term observing programs at Lick Observatory. (b) Collaboration with a large international team of astronomers to carry out the most intensive and detailed reverberation mapping study ever conducted, a 15-month observing program on the galaxy Markarian 817, using multiple ground-based and space-based telescopes. The data revealed a wealth of information on the physical properties of the accretion disk in Mrk 817 and on outflows of gas launched from the innermost regions around its black hole. (c) The first-ever reverberation mapping measurements for a gravitationally lensed quasar at high redshift, providing the most precise determination of a quasar's black hole mass ever obtained for such a distant black hole using the reverberation method. (d) Detection of the shortest optical continuum reverberation time delays ever measured, in the dwarf galaxy NGC 4395, which contains one of the smallest central black holes known in any nearby galaxy. The results indicate an accretion disk size some two orders of magnitude smaller than the disk sizes found in more typical AGN. (e) Participation in numerous large, collaborative monitoring programs for bright AGN using observations from the robotic telescopes of Las Cumbres Observatory. (f) Measurement of continuum reverberation time delays in a sample of nearly 100 quasars using data from the Zwicky Transient Factory survey. Together, these continuum reverberation mapping programs found results that are partially consistent with theoretical predictions for standard accretion disk structure, but the reverberation time delays are typically 3-4 times longer than predicted, indicating that black hole accretion disk sizes might be 3-4 times larger than expected from standard disk models. An alternative explanation that gains increasing support from these data is that the continuum reverberation time delays are due to not just the accretion disk itself but also the surrounding ionized regions (the "broad-line region", which is larger than the accretion disk).

Another component of this project involved carrying out near-infrared spectroscopic observations at the Keck Observatory of very distant quasars at redshifts of 7 and above, corresponding to a time when the universe was less than 800 million years old. These observations aided in confirming the discoveries of several of the most distant known quasars, and in determining the masses of their central black holes. Remarkably, the black holes in these early quasars are already in the range of 1 billion Solar masses, and comparison with black hole growth models indicates that they must have formed from heavy "seed" black holes having initial masses of order 10,000 Solar masses or larger.

This grant supported the Ph.D. thesis research of one graduate student and the research of one postdoctoral scholar at UC Irvine. Additionally, the PI carried out academic-year and summer mentoring activities and research supervision for undergraduate students from California State University campuses as part of the Cal-Bridge mentoring program.
